keyTakeAways: The Gen Z movement in Madagascar, initially formed to address recurring water and power outages, has evolved into a powerful force demanding political transparency and structural change.
The appointment of Herintsalama Rajaonarivelo as prime minister by Col Michael Randrianirina has been criticized by Gen Z Mada as non-transparent and unconsulted, undermining the movement's goals.
Gen Z Mada claims Rajaonarivelo's ties to the previous government make his appointment a betrayal of the revolution's intent to break from past political failures.
The youth-led protests initially sparked by infrastructure issues have now become a central driver of political transformation, pushing for accountability and democratic reform.

Col Michael Randrianirina’s military-led seizure of power in late October 2025 and subsequent swearing-in as head of state was framed as a response to public demands, with an explicit acknowledgment of youth mobilization.

summaryOfNewsArticle: In Madagascar, a youth-led movement called Gen Z Mada, which emerged from protests over water and power outages, is now opposing the appointment of businessman Herintsalama Rajaonarivelo as prime minister by newly installed head of state Col Michael Randrianirina. The youth group criticizes the appointment as non-transparent and unconsulted, claiming it violates the movement's goal of structural political change and undermines their revolution. The movement asserts that Rajaonarivelo’s ties to the previous government, led by President Andry Rajoelina, represent a betrayal of reform. The political crisis followed Rajoelina’s failure to quell protests and his subsequent flight from the country, after which Col Randrianirina, leader of the elite CAPSAT unit, took power in a military-backed transition. The youth movement remains vigilant, threatening continued mobilization unless the appointment is explained or reversed, signaling an ongoing struggle between democratic reform and military intervention in Madagascar’s governance.
title: Madagascar Gen Z protesters angry at choice of new PM Rajaonarivelo
